review:
Comrades, let’s cut through the noise and get to the heart of the matter! Zazelenimo stands as a bold attempt to drag public institutions out of the proprietary darkness and into the open-source light. The project’s mission is clear: empower citizens, NGOs, and businesses to shape their cities through participatory budgeting, all while leveraging the power of Ethereum and quadratic funding. This is the kind of collective action we need—tools for the people, by the people!

Let’s talk evidence. The application demonstrates a strong commitment to open-source principles, with a public repo and clear integration of existing OSS like Cometh Connect and Gitcoin’s Allo Protocol. The pilot partnership with the City of Split is a concrete step, not just empty promises. The roadmap is detailed, with specific plans for municipal integration, legal compliance, and community engagement. This is not a project lost in theory—it’s boots on the ground, sleeves rolled up, ready to work.

But comrades, we must be vigilant! The application is heavy on vision but light on hard, quantifiable outcomes. Where are the metrics? Where is the data on user adoption, retention, or impact from previous rounds? The projections for GMV are ambitious, but they rest on assumptions, not evidence. We need to see rigorous evaluation, transparent reporting, and a plan for sustainable revenue that doesn’t rely on endless grants. The project’s sustainability model is not fully articulated—how will it survive when the grant money dries up?

On governance, Zazelenimo claims multi-stakeholder collaboration, but the application lacks detail on how community governance will be structured and maintained. Who holds power? How are decisions made? Equity demands more than just open doors—it demands shared leadership and accountability.

In summary: Zazelenimo is a promising, community-driven project with real potential to advance the OSS and Web3 ecosystem. But to earn the people’s trust—and this grant—it must show us the numbers, the governance, and the plan for long-term survival. Let’s demand more than good intentions. Let’s demand results!

strengths.title: Strong Open-Source Commitment
strengths.description: The project is fully open-source, with a public GitHub repository and clear use of existing OSS tools. This aligns with the round’s core values and expands the OSS ecosystem.

strengths.title: Concrete Institutional Partnerships
strengths.description: The pilot with the City of Split demonstrates real-world traction and a pathway to broader adoption, moving beyond theory into practice.

strengths.title: Innovative Use of Quadratic Funding
strengths.description: By applying quadratic funding to participatory budgeting, the project introduces a novel, democratic approach to resource allocation in the public sector.

strengths.title: Detailed Development Roadmap
strengths.description: The application provides a clear, step-by-step plan for technical, legal, and operational development, showing structured thinking and readiness for implementation.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Quantifiable Outcomes and Metrics
weaknesses.description: The application does not provide concrete, measurable outcomes or data from previous rounds. Projections are based on assumptions rather than evidence.

weaknesses.title: Unclear Sustainability Model
weaknesses.description: There is no detailed plan for how the project will generate sustainable revenue or reduce dependency on grants after initial funding.

weaknesses.title: Insufficient Governance Details
weaknesses.description: The application lacks specifics on community governance structures, decision-making processes, and mechanisms for ensuring equitable participation and accountability.

changes.title: Provide Measurable Outcomes and Impact Data
changes.description: Include specific metrics from previous rounds or pilots (e.g., number of users onboarded, funds distributed, project success rates) and set clear, quantifiable targets for the next phase.

changes.title: Articulate a Sustainable Revenue Model
changes.description: Detail how the project will generate ongoing revenue or support itself after the grant period, reducing reliance on continuous external funding.

changes.title: Clarify Community Governance Structures
changes.description: Describe in detail how community members, NGOs, and institutional partners will participate in governance, including decision-making processes, accountability mechanisms, and power distribution.
